ai-sn2:25.1.2_0: At one time several mendicants were staying in the Kosalan lands, in a wilderness hut on the slopes of the Himalayas. They were restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, loose-tongued, unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.
ai-sn2:25.2.1_0: Then on the fifteenth day sabbath the god Jantu went to those mendicants.
ai-sn2:25.2.1_1: and after approaching he addressed the mendicants in verse:
ai-sn2:25.3.5_0: Knowing that the world was impermanent
ai-sn2:25.3.6_0: they made an end of suffering.
ai-sn2:25.4.1_0: But now they’ve made themselves hard to look after,

ai-sn2:25.5.1_0: Having raised my joined palms to the Saṅgha,
ai-sn2:25.5.2_0: I say that some people are a killer.

ai-sn2:26.1.2_0: Standing to one side, the god Rohitassa said to the Buddha,
ai-sn2:26.1.3_0: “Sir, is it possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn?”
ai-sn2:26.1.4_0: “Reverend, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn.”
ai-sn2:26.2.2_0: how well said this was by Master Gotama. He repeated the Buddha’s verses, and said:
ai-sn2:26.2.3_0: ‘Reverend, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn.’
ai-sn2:26.3.1_0: Once upon a time, I was a hermit called Rohitassa, son of Bhoja. I was a sky-walker with psychic power.
ai-sn2:26.3.2_0: I was the dust-free, reverend Sir,
ai-sn2:26.3.2_1: Suppose there was a well-trained expert archers with a strong bow. They’d easily shot arrows invade and shake them off.

ai-sn2:26.3.5_0: ‘I will reach the end of the world by traveling.’
ai-sn2:26.3.6_0: Having such speed and stride, I traveled for my whole lifespan of a hundred years—pausing only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness—and I passed away along the way, never reaching the end of the world.
ai-sn2:26.4.2_0: how well said this was by Master Gotama. He repeated the Buddha’s verses, and said:
ai-sn2:26.4.3_0: ‘Reverend, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn.’”
ai-sn2:26.5.1_0: “But Reverend, I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.
ai-sn2:26.5.2_0: For it is in this fathom-long carcass with its perception and mind that I describe the world, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.
ai-sn2:26.6.1_0: He should not be attained by going,

ai-sn2:26.7.3_0: A peaceful one, knowing the end of the world,

ai-sn2:30.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn2:30.1.3_0: Then, late at night, several glorious gods lit up the entire Bamboo Grove. They were Asama, Sahalī, Niṅka, Ākoṭaka, Vetambarī, and Māṇavagāmiya. They went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.
ai-sn2:30.1.4_0: Standing to one side, the god Asama recited this verse about Pūraṇa Kassapa in the Buddha’s presence:
ai-sn2:30.2.3_0: do not regard them as evil,
ai-sn2:30.2.5_0: What he taught should truly be trusted,
ai-sn2:30.2.6_0: he’s worthy of esteem as Teacher.”
ai-sn2:30.3.1_0: Then the god Sahalī recited this verse about Makkhali Gosala in the Buddha’s presence:
ai-sn2:30.4.1_0: “Through mortification in disgust of sin he became well restrained.
ai-sn2:30.4.2_0: He gave up arguing with people.
ai-sn2:30.4.3_0: Refraining from false speech, he spoke the truth.
ai-sn2:30.4.4_0: for surely you don’t do bad deeds with such idios!”
ai-sn2:30.5.1_0: Then the god Niṅka recited this verse about Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta in the Buddha’s presence:
ai-sn2:30.6.2_0: well restrained in the four controls;
ai-sn2:30.6.3_0: explaining what is seen and heard:
ai-sn2:30.6.4_0: surely not you wouldn’t be able to do.”
ai-sn2:30.7.1_0: Then the god Ākoṭaka recited this verse about various sectarian teachers in the Buddha’s presence:
ai-sn2:30.8.1_0: He said to the Jain ascetics,
ai-sn2:30.8.2_0: as well as this Makkhali and Pūraṇa:
ai-sn2:30.8.4_0: surely they weren’t far from truly good men!”
ai-sn2:30.9.1_0: Then the god Vetambarī replied to the god Ākoṭaka in verse:
ai-sn2:30.10.3_0: the Teacher, who does not lie,
ai-sn2:30.10.4_0: though they teach a community, doesn’t resemble the good.”
ai-sn2:30.11.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked took possession of the god Vetambarī and recited this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
ai-sn2:30.12.1_0: “Those dedicated to mortification in disgust of sin,
ai-sn2:30.12.3_0: and those who are drawn away from form,
ai-sn2:30.12.4_0: they rejoice in the heavenly realm.
ai-sn2:30.13.1_0: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
ai-sn2:30.14.1_0: “Whatever forms there are in this world or the world beyond,
ai-sn2:30.14.2_0: and those of shining beauty in the sky,
ai-sn2:30.14.3_0: all of these you praise, Namuci,
ai-sn2:30.14.4_0: like bait tossed out for catching fish.”
ai-sn2:30.15.1_0: Then the god Māṇavagāmiya recited this verse about the Buddha in his presence:
ai-sn2:30.16.2_0: Vipula’s said to be the best.
ai-sn2:30.16.3_0: Seta is the best of the Himalayan peaks,
ai-sn2:30.16.4_0: and the sun, of travelers in space.
ai-sn2:30.17.1_0: The ocean is the best of seas,
ai-sn2:30.17.2_0: like the moon on the fifteenth day.
ai-sn2:30.17.3_0: in all the world with its gods,
ai-sn2:30.17.5_0: The third sub-chapter on different religions is finished.
ai-sn2:30.18.4_0: Do you have fun with various sectarians?
ai-sn2:30.18.5_0: The Linked Discourses on Gods are complete.
